PUSPIPTEK South Tangerang, Banten 15314, Indonesia g College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jishou University, Jishou 416000, Hunan, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Jishou University Jishou Hunan 416000 China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jishou University, Jishou 416000, Hunan, China * Corresponding author # Corresponding author Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have been widely used in heterogeneous catalysis owing to the maximum utilization of metal-active sites with controlled structures and well-defined locations. Upon tailored coordination with nitrogen atom, the metal-nitrogen (M-N)-based SACs have demonstrated interesting physical, optical and electronic properties and have become intense in photocatalysis and electrocatalysis in the past decade. Despite substantial efforts in constructing various M–N-based SACs, the principles for modulating the intrinsic photocatalytic and electrocatalytic performance of their active sites and catalytic mechanism have not been sufficiently studied. Herein, the present review intends to shed some light on recent research made in studying the correlation between intrinsic electronic structure, catalytic mechanism, single-metal atom (SMA) confinement and their photocatalytic and electrocatalytic activities (conversion, selectivity, stability and etc). Based on the analysis of fundamentals of M–N-based SACs, theoretical calculations and experimental investigations, including synthetic methods and characterization techniques, are both included to provide an integral understanding of the underlying mechanisms behind improved coordination structure and observed activity. Finally, the challenges and perspectives for constructing highly active M–N based photocatalysis and electrocatalysis SACs are provided. In particular, extensive technical and mechanism aspects are thoroughly discussed, summarized and analyzed for promoting further advancement of M-N-based SACs in photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. Graphical abstract N-coordinated SMA catalysts exhibit unique catalytic performance in various reactions. This review explores the intimate correlation of intrinsic electronic structure, catalytic mechanism, and different electron states of SMA confinement. Keywords N-coordinated single-atom catalyst Photocatalysis Electrocatalysis Electronic structure Active site 1 Introduction Many new technologies for the improvement of our societies have been developed due to recent energy and environmental problems [1–6]. Energy conversion technologies are essential in the production of environmentally friendly energy fuels. The most common clean energy technologies, which convert solar and electrical energies into chemical energy, such as photocatalytic, electrocatalytic, or photo(electro)catalytic hydrogen-evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and CO2 reduction reaction (CRR), have been considered as candidate technologies for overcoming energy and environment crises [7–14]. The key to these energy conversion technologies lies in the chemical constituents of the catalysts. However, most catalytic reactions are mainly harnessed by noble metal-based (NMB) catalysts, which are cost-intensive [15–21]. Therefore, the development of efficient and low-cost catalysts is needed to replace NMB catalysts [22,23]. Various NMB catalysts have been developed to drive different reactions. In 2011, Zhang et al. [24] investigated single-atom catalysts (SACs) with atomically isolated metal-active sites as catalysts. In recent years, single-metal atom (SMA) photocatalysts and electrocatalysts have gradually attracted increased attention. Fig. 1 demonstrates that about 30–41 SAC-based photocatalysts and electrocatalysts were reported in Science in 2016. Meanwhile, a considerable number of publications concerning SMA photocatalysts and electrocatalysts have been reported over the next few years (Fig. 1). Studies have demonstrated that SACs exhibit excellent activity and selectivity compared with metal nanoclusters and nanoparticles [25–31]. More importantly, its catalytic reaction mechanisms are relatively straightforward due to unambiguous structures [32–35]. Thus, SACs demonstrate excellent catalytic performance during catalytic reactions. Decreasing metal size can decrease active metal utilization [36–40]. When a metal reaches atomic dispersion, the atom utilization efficiency can reach 100% in principle [41–45]. In this case, the catalytic processes and mechanisms are associated with the resolved structural interpretation via density functional theory (DFT) calculations. In theory, the valence state of SMAs on support should be zero, but this may not be exactly the case [46]. Due to the high surface energy, single atoms tend to aggregate on the support surface [47–53]. Thus, if a metal is atomically dispersed, the metal atoms should be confined by external support. As SMAs are confined by covalent coordination, their valence states are not zero [49]. Therefore, the formation of covalent coordination bonds could stabilize SMAs via metal atom coordination [54,55], surface defect or vacancy and anchoring sites [56,57], and spatial confinement strategy [58] (Fig. 2 ). Furthermore, the covalent coordination bonds between a single atom and support are usually S-M [59–62], C-M [20,28,34,63–65], N-M [30,66–71], O-M [72–78], and so on. SACs were first applied in the electrocatalytic ORR area [24]. The footprint of SACs has developed in other electrocatalytic, even photocatalytic, areas, with significant applications in photocatalytic and electrocatalytic HERs [79–82], ORRs [39,83–87], and CRRs [27,29,88–91]. Metal atoms coordinated by N atom (M-N)-based SACs afford state-of-the-art photocatalytic and electrocatalytic performances, which are consequently considered as a promising candidate for practical photoelectrocatalytic applications owing to their easy application preparation. The lone-pair electrons could be easily captured in SMAs. In a typical M-N structure, the single-atom center is stabilized by coordinated N atoms. Previous studies have demonstrated that M-N-based SACs show excellent performance in both photocatalytic and electrocatalytic areas. For instance, Chen et al. [92] indicated that the η 10, HER of Fe-N-C could reach −202 mV in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH, which led to a comparable performance to the famous traditional catalysts Pt/C. DFT calculations revealed that the single Fe site favored H* adsorption, and enhanced HER performance was achieved. Li and coworkers [93] demonstrated that Ni-N4-C SACs had more than 90% Faradic efficiency toward CO. In all reactions involving photocatalysts or electrocatalysts, the single M-N sites usually serve as the active sites. Although many advantages have been achieved, a considerable amount of effort is still needed to improve M-N-based SACs to replace NMB catalysts. Therefore, in this study, we summarize SACs for photocatalytic and electrocatalytic reactions. We focus on the synthesis method, photo(electro)catalytic application, and reaction mechanism for M-N-based SACs. Furthermore, we believe that this review will provide useful insights and practical guidance for the construction of highly efficient M-N-based SACs for photo(electro)catalytic applications. 2 Fundamentals of M-N-based SACs 2.1 Fundamentals of M-N-based SACs for photocatalytic applications Photocatalytic reactions usually proceed in the following four steps: (1) photon harvesting, (2) light excitation, (3) separation and transfer of photogenerated electrons and holes, and (4) oxidation-reduction reactions at the surface-active sites. Meanwhile, the photogenerated electron-hole pairs also recombine in semiconductors, which significantly decreases photocatalytic performance. Accelerating surface reaction kinetics and improving surface-active sites are effective methods for avoiding the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. Many M-N-based SACs, such as Pt, Co, and Ni, have been successfully used in photocatalytic areas. The M-N-based SACs demonstrate excellent photocatalytic performance and are highly selective. This review proposes and extensively discusses the relationship between electronic structure and photocatalytic performance. 2.2 Fundamentals of M-N-based SACs for electrocatalytic applications Electrochemical water splitting directly converts water into clean hydrogen energy. Minimizing reaction kinetics is a promising method for enhancing electrocatalytic HER and OER efficiencies. The key HER performance metric is the overpotential needed to exceed the HER or OER current density at −10 mA cm−2. Typically, electrocatalytic HER is divided into multistep electrochemical processes. Depending on the electrolyte pH, the electrochemical steps follow two different pathways. The first step relates to electrochemical hydrogen adsorption in an acid or alkaline solution [94]. (1) In acid solution: H+ + * + e− → H* (2) In alkaline solution: H2O + * + e− → H* + OH− The following steps may significantly differ depending on the H* coverage. When the H* coverage is low, the hydrogen-evolution step may follow the Heyrovsky reaction. (3) In acid solution: H+ + H* + e− → H2 + * (4) In alkaline solution: H2O + H* + e− → * + OH− + H2 In a high H* coverage situation, the hydrogen-evolution step may follow the Tafel reaction. (5) Both in alkaline and acid solution: 2H* → H2 + The H* largely depends on the active site's inherent properties due to a single H atom chemically adsorbed on the active site [94]. In contrast, OER usually exhibits a slow kinetic in the half-reaction, which is a limiting factor that inhibits overall water splitting. The OER follows the following pathways: (6) 2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e− (7) 4OH− → O2 + 2H2O + 4e− Eqs. (6) and (7) occur in acidic and alkaline media [95]. Therefore, exploring high-efficiency OER electrocatalysts for overall water splitting is imperative. Although NMB electrocatalysts have demonstrated excellent performance, the rare abundance of noble metal restricts their further applications. For example, these materials cannot show excellent simultaneous performance in acidic or alkaline media [96]. Recently, M-N-C SACs have been widely used in electrocatalytic OER owing to their clear structural active sites. In theory, the valence state of SMAs on support should be zero, but this may not be the case [46]. SMAs tend to aggregate on the support owing to their high surface energy [47–49]. As metal particles usually aggregate with a broad size in traditional heterogeneous catalysts, numerous metal particles cannot contact the reaction, even triggering undesired side reactions, thereby inducing insufficient exploration of active sites and significant waste of atom utilization. Although homogeneous catalysts exhibit excellent activity and selectivity due to their clear structural active sites and tunable coordination environments, their stability and recyclability cannot satisfy the practical requirements. Fortunately, SACs can circumvent the aforementioned issues and hold great potential to synergize heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts. Therefore, SACs have several advantages over their nanoclusters and nanoparticles. They have unsaturated coordination sites and unique electronic structures that induce high activity and selectivity, provide sufficient exploration of active sites and significantly reduce the use of atoms, and are easily observed in the reaction process due to precise atom structures as active sites. This review will now discuss several factors relating to the coordinated environment, electronic structure, and underlying catalytic mechanism in HER, OER, and CO2 reduction applications of various M-N-C SMAs. 2.3 Advantages and challenges of M-N-based SACs In photocatalytic and electrocatalytic reactions, the surface reaction usually occurs at the surface-active sites. The reaction system is directly contacted by the M-N active site in electrocatalytic applications. Although every metal atom is involved in the catalytic reaction, the M–N bond effectively decreases the reaction ΔG compared with the bulk electrocatalytic active sites. Thus, M-N-based single-atom electrocatalysts usually exhibit low overpotential in water splitting and are highly selective in CO2 reduction [39,97]. In addition, the M-N sites at the semiconductor surface usually serve as cocatalysts. The photogenerated electrons are transferred to surface-active sites [89,98]. Thus, the photocatalytic reactions are divided into two parts: light-harvesting and electrocatalytic reactions. The M-N-based single-atom photocatalysts exhibit excellent photocatalytic performance in water splitting and are highly selective in CO2 reduction compared with bulk cocatalysts. Light harvesting is another factor affecting the photocatalytic performance of semiconductor photocatalysts. Traditional bulk cocatalysts on semiconductor surfaces block the semiconductor's light harvest. As the SMA size is usually less than 0.5 nm [21], the small-sized SMAs slightly affect semiconductor photon harvesting. Meanwhile, the lone-pair electrons of N atoms are easily captured in metal atoms compared with the P, S, and O elements [94,99]. The SMAs in M-P, M-S, and M-O are usually confirmed by defective sites that demand support. Although SMAs can easily be adsorbed at the low-index oxide facets [100], they tend to aggregate the metal atoms toward nanoparticles at the high-index oxide facets [101], which is highly demanding for support. Meanwhile, defective sites in photocatalytic trap the carriers during the photocatalytic process, thereby significantly decreasing the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes. SMAs suffer the same problem in M-P and M-S [102–104]. However, support for N-M-based SACs is not in high demand (such as MOF-derived nitrogen-doped graphene/carbon and g-C3N4 (gCN)). Thus, M-N-based SACs are easily prepared compared with other SMAs, such as M-C, M-P, M-S, and M-O (Fig. 3 ). However, although M-N-based SACs have demonstrated excellent catalytic performance in photocatalytic and electrocatalytic areas, the fundamental understanding of their mechanism remains unclear. In other words, the way electrons are involved in the reaction at the active sites remains partially understood. In situ testing should be simultaneously considered and optimized to better understand the catalytic reaction process. Previous studies have usually focused on the reaction energy of reactant adsorption and product desorption, neglecting the valance state and components of active sites (single-metal sites). In addition, the loading amounts of single-metal sites as active sites remain below 0.5%. Thus, enhancing the amount of SMAs is necessary. In this review, we summarize several types of M-N-based SACs utilized in photocatalytic and electrocatalytic reactions. Furthermore, we extensively review their catalytic performance based on their inherent peculiar structures and corresponding mechanistic approaches to determine their unique structures and physical properties. First, we summarize the synthesis method for M-N-based SACs and highlight the development of solar-to-chemical energy conversions, such as HER, OER, COR, and N2 fixation. Second, we define M-N-based SACs by referring them to electrocatalysts with atomically dispersed active sites by combining in situ characterization techniques and DFT calculations. Finally, we summarize the review with some prospective insights into the future design of M-N-based SACs. 3 Synthesis methods of M-N-based SACs Metal atoms with high surface energy tend to aggregate into nanoparticles [105–107]. Therefore, avoiding SMA aggregation is critical for developing efficient and stable SACs. The N atoms in M-N-based SACs are usually bonded with metal and carbon. Thus, the M-N-based SACs are usually anchored on the N-doped carbon materials and gCN [31,66,108–111] (Fig. 4 ). To prepare efficient and stable SACs, the following three conditions are required: (1) few amounts of metal atoms, (2) existence of vacancies and defects on the supporting surface, and (3) existence of strong coordination bond between SMAs and support. Until now, numerous methods have been developed for fabricating SACs, such as the defect engineering strategy [75,112], coordination design strategy [97,113], spatial confinement strategy [85,114], and high-temperature pyrolysis (HTP) [115]. Fig. 5 presents the advantages and necessary conditions for different synthesis methods of M-N-based SACs. Next, we discuss recent developments in constructing M-N-based SACs, emphasizing the three issues pertinent to photocatalytic and electrocatalytic applications. 3.1 HTP method The HTP method is usually used to obtain SACs via thermal decomposition of precursors above 600 °C [115,116] The metal organic framework (MOF)-based precursor mixtures with metal and carbon sources often serve as thermal decomposition precursors. The HTPs of different precursors result in different atomic structures, thus achieving different catalytic performances. For example, metal nodes and organic linkers are uniformly distributed in MOFs. The metal atoms could be uniformly dispersed with organic linkers in the framework during the synthesis process, transferring to SACs following HTP treatment. The metal nodes in the MOFs often serve as SMA sites and are distributed to SACs by HTP treatment to prevent metal center aggregation. However, N-rich organic linkers of MOFs usually serve as precursors to stabilize SACs owing to the more robust metal-nitrogen coordination bond. The stronger metal-nitrogen maintains stability at high temperatures. Therefore, zinc-based bimetallic zeolitic imidazole frameworks are generally used as precursors to stabilize SMAs with similar Zn2+ sizes. Under pyrolysis treatment, the metal atoms substitute the Zn atom sites at ~906 °C. The Zn atoms evaporate, and the SMAs coordinate with nitrogen-rich organic linkers following HTP treatment. For instance, Wu et al. constructed Fe-N-C catalysts by inserting Zn and Fe atoms into ZIF metal nodes using Zn-N4 complexes and tetrahedral Fe-N4 structures (Fig. 6(a) ). After thermal activation treatments, the tetrahedral Fe-N4 structures were converted into the FeN4 active sites in the carbon matrix. The Zn atoms in the ZIF structure were simultaneously evaporated to form porous carbon structures during HTP [117]. Aside from the Fe atoms, the Co atoms can be combined with the Zn atoms to form bimetallic ZIFs. Manthiram and his coworkers inserted Co ions into the Zn2+(ZIF-8) framework (Fig. 6(b)). The Zn2+(ZIF-8)/Co2+(ZIF-67) was transferred into a Co- and N-codoped porous carbon nanotube upon HTP treatment. The Zn and Co molar ratio determines the number of Co-N x moieties [118]. An MOF structure mainly comprises a porous network apart from the linkage between organic linkers and metal nodes. These cages could also confine the metal atoms to prevent undesired aggregation. An MOF's pore size should exceed that of a metal atom so that the SMA can be confined in the MOF cage. For example, Li et al. [119] found that ZIF-8 could serve as a host to confine the Ru3(CO)12 molecule with a smaller dimension (8.0 Å) compared with the ZIF-8 pore size (11.6 Å). Notably, a single Ru3(CO)12 molecule is stable inside the ZIF-8 cage. Upon HTP treatment (Fig. 6(c)), the isolated Ru3(CO)12 molecules confined in the cells of ZIF-8 were decomposed such that the nitrogen species stabilized uniform Ru single atoms. A pyrolysis environment is imperative for producing M-N-based SACs. As a result, N-containing irregular complexes or polymers have been widely used as precursors for constructing M-N-based SACs (M = Fe [97,120–122], Co [95,123,124], Ni [39,125], and Cu [126–128]). For example, Ni and free-radical polymerization of acrylonitrile were combined to design polyacrylonitrile-derived Ni (Ni-PACN). The Ni-PACN was stabilized at 230 °C in the O2 atmosphere and subsequently pyrolyzed at 900 °C to obtain the final Ni-PACN SACs. Here we assume that the weight ratio of the Ni loadings could reach 3.4%. Based on this modified structure, Ni SMAs were coordinated with four N atoms. Common organic sources, such as urea, melamine, and dicyandiamide, are categorized as promising precursors for gCN polymerization. The layered gCN formation served as a support to confine the SMAs. Song et al. [129] confined SMAs to the gCN framework by heating dicyandiamide at 600 °C to form layered gCN. Then, the gCN-metal precursor was transferred to the metal-N center by heating the gCN-metal precursor at 750 °C. In addition, 4 N atoms stabilized the single Fe atoms at the graphene lattices (Fig. 7(a) ). As a result, 4.6 wt% Fe single atoms stabilized at the graphene lattices were achieved [92,129–131]. N-containing irregular polymers usually serve as precursors to anchor single metals and subsequent pyrolysis to design carbon-based SACs [42,123,124,132,133]. For example, using high nitrogen content as a precursor, Yuan et al. [132] polymerized PPy-based hydrogel polymerized with FeCl3 such that the Fe ions were coordinated with the N atoms (Fig. 7(b)). Upon pyrolysis of PPy-Fe at 800 °C and acid leaching treatment, uniformly dispersed atomic Fe-N x sites were obtained. Li et al. [84] pioneered the conversion of pyrrole, thiophene, and Fe(acac)3 terpolymer into Fe-PPy-co-PTh after pyrolyzing them at 900 °C. Thus, the copolymer of PPy-co-PTh can be formulated into nitrogen-doped porous carbon and Fe(acac)3, which, at a later stage, can be extracted into Fe single atoms. Here, the Fe single atoms were stabilized by four Fe–N bonds (Fig. 7(c)). Though the M-N-based SACs obtained using the HTP method are easily prepared, they induce enormous demands on the precursor. Meanwhile, after HTP treatment, the obtained sample requires acid treatment, which wastes a tremendous amount of metal. In addition, the electronic and atomic structures are often uncontrolled. Thus, controlling the electronic and atomic structures decreases metal atoms’ waste. The degree of pyrolysis also affects the bond character of M-N. Li et al. [134] found that, with a pyrolysis temperature of 100–1000 °C, the average diameter of metal nanoparticles gradually increased, suggesting that aggregation and atomization coexisted during the conversion from nanoparticles to SMAs. Both aggregation and atomization were enhanced when the temperature exceeded 1000 °C, and the nanoparticles gradually transformed into SMAs. The SMA content gradually increased as the pyrolysis temperature increased. The DFT results indicated that sintering occurred at a relatively low temperature (~300–900 °C). In contrast, atomization existed at high temperatures (above 1000 °C) [134]. Pyrolysis temperature also affected the coordinated structure of the SACs. Fe was atomized, forming FeNx (x = 4–6), and the coordination number depended on the pyrolysis temperature. The FeNx structure became more symmetric as the pyrolysis temperature increased [135]. 3.2 Chemical and physical interactions Due to the metal atoms’ high surface energy, they can form particle aggregation during the synthesis process. Thus, current knowledge of the interaction between supports and metal atoms is imperative to prevent undesired metal atom aggregations. Notably, semiconductors are widely used as light-harvesting materials for anchoring metal atoms. The semiconductors hold great potential to stabilize SMAs owing to their abundant chemical groups and vacancies or defects, which act as the anchoring sites for metal atom stabilization. SMAs could directly bond with the surface ligands without occupying other atom sites when stabilized by vacancies or defects [54,55]. SMAs stabilized by vacancies or defects and surface ligands exhibit different performances during the reaction process. For example, SMAs bond with surface ligands, which induce active SMAs on the support surface, thereby causing the SMAs to come into contact with the reaction system. Although this method causes SMA overexposure, the SMAs in the defects or vacancies are more thermodynamically stable than those bonded onto surface ligands [98,136]. In addition, the diameter of the SMAs should be smaller than that of the defects or vacancies to enable the SMAs to fit onto the topmost semiconductor surface. The valance state of SMAs can be determined using their vacancies within the system. When the anionic vacancy stabilizes the SMAs, the valance state value of the SMAs is positive and vice versa. Surface organometallic catalysts are similar to SACs. SACs and surface organometallic catalysts are confined to SMAs by being embedded, attached, and immobilized in or on support (Fig. 8 ). The support for SACs mainly focuses on carbon materials, carbon nitrides, MOF, and COF. In surface organometallic catalysis, many supports have been measured, including oxygen-containing materials (e.g., silica, MOF, and zeolites). Both SACs and surface organometallic catalysts have been widely analyzed for various catalytic reactions on SMAs. These reactions have similarities and differences. Compared with SACs, an SMA ionically or covalently bound to the support is a surface organometallic catalyst. In surface organometallic catalysis, organometallic complexes react with well-defined surfaces, such as oxide, carbon, or graphene, to form a reactive site to achieve the target reaction. Their ligand remnants keep at least a part after grafting for surface organometallic catalysis [137,138]. 3.2.1 Coordination design strategy The high surface energy of metal atoms enables them to aggregate on the support surface. However, coordinate sites can serve as SMA immobilization to prevent aggregation and simultaneously promote SAC formation. N atoms with long electron pairs can coordinate with metal atoms to form SACs. Notably, long pairs of N atoms for N-doped graphene, MOFs, COFs, etc. are widely used as supports to anchor single-metal sites (Figs. 9(a)–(d) ) [56,92,140–142]. Recently, gCNs with hexagonal building blocks are abundant with N atoms that periodically separate could stabilize SMAs. The N atom's long pair of electrons could adsorb and bond with metal precursors. Therefore, numerous gCN-based supports are compatible for creating M-N-based SACs, such as Pt [31,143,144], Co [90,145,146], Ni [147], Ag [17], Pd [148], Au [149], and Ru [109]. For instance, Zheng et al. [145] developed a range of molecule-level SACs based on the gCN. The Co-N2 center is the active center in the ORR and OER. The length of the Co-N atoms is 1.55 Å. Here, Co2+ can be used as an active center that exhibits excellent CO2 reduction selectivity toward CO formation, with a TOF exceeding 200 [145]. Jiang et al. [140] implanted Pt ions into the center of porphyrin linkers and thereby can be reduced using H2 gas. The atomically dispersed Pt had a loading amount of 0.07 wt%–0.29 wt% according to the loading amount of K2PtCl4 (Fig. 9(a)). Four N atoms stabilize Pt single atoms, demonstrating a promising activity with a turnover frequency of 35 h−1, ~30 folds compared with that of the pristine [140]. Similarly, Pan and his coworkers synthesized Fe-N4 active center-based SACs for overall water-splitting applications (Fig. 9(b)). The metal atoms were first anchored in the large ring cavity in the phthalocyanine. The PPc linkers were then implemented to adjust the metal site distances. Upon pyrolysis at 920 °C, the PPc linkers were thermally decomposed into NPC simultaneously with Fe single atoms in situ anchoring on NPC. As a result, the Fe-N4 site exhibited efficient electrocatalytic activity for ORR, OER, and HER [92]. In addition, Wurster et al. [56] successfully formulated bimetallic SACs by subliming the second metal. The SACs were prepared as monolayers in an ultra-high vacuum on a clean Au (111) surface (Fig. 9(c)). The four N atoms stabilized Au atoms to form the metal pyridyl-porphyrin (M1TPyP). Thus, a second single-metal center site was created. Apart from Au SMAs, Co and Fe single atoms could also serve as single-metal center sites [56]. N-doped graphene or carbon has been widely used in M-N-based SACs as a support owing to its large specific surface area and rich anchoring sites [88,150–152]. For example, Pan and his coworkers used hollow N-doped porous carbon spheres to stabilize the Co single atoms using a Co-N5 structure (Fig. 9(d)). The strong interaction between cobalt phthalocyanine and N in porous carbon spheres induced the Co-N5 structure. The Co-N5 single centers act as the active center during the CRR with CO selectivity approaching 100% [88]. Although excellent stability of SMAs has been shown from the above analysis, the requirement to synthesize such candidates is incredibly nontrivial. Here, we must consider diverse parameters, such as pH, solvents, and temperature, which are imperative in constructing M-N-based SACs. Therefore, precisely controlling the electronic structure is critical for successfully constructing M-N-based SACs. In addition, the surrounding coordination environments can affect the valance state of SMAs. Therefore, the choice of metal atoms and supports is imperative in the construction of M-N-based SACs. 3.2.2 Spatial confinement strategy SMAs can be confined to an individual hole. Thus, the spatial confinement strategy is widely used to anchor M-N-based SMAs. SMAs were first stabilized by encapsulating suitable mononuclear or multinuclear, such as zeolites [57,153,154] and MOFs [58]. Then, the ligands of the precursors were removed, and SMAs were stabilized within the support's framework. Zeolites with labile ligands as precursors can be converted into cationic complexes in solutions. Zeolites offer multiple cationic center sites in frameworks where metal atoms can be anchored via an ion-exchange process. For instance, subnanometric Pt could be confined by the MWW precursor during the swelling process (Fig. 10(a) ). The subnanometric Pt species and surfactant molecules were dispersed between the layers. After calcining at 540 °C, the organic surfactant was removed, and the remaining super cages of MCM-2 encapsulated Pt single atoms [57] MOFs can serve as interconnected pore supports, in which their framework confines the atomic dispersion of metal atoms for M-N-based SAC construction. For example, using MOF-525 (Zr6O4(OH)4(TCPP-H2)3 [TCPP = 4,4′,4′′,4′′′-(porphyrin-5,10,15, 20-tetrayl) tetrabenzoate]) with Zr6clus-ters and porphyrin-based molecular as hosts, the unsaturated Co atoms were anchored at the porphyrin units to form MOF-525-Co-SACs (Fig. 10(b)). Thus, each Co atom is fully exposed to the CO2 atmosphere and prohibits aggregation into undesired nanoparticles [89]. Wang et al. [58] designed a simple method for constructing SACs with zirconium-porphyrinic MOF hollow nanotube-noble metals, such as Pd, Pt, Au, Ir, and Ru. In essence, synthesized zirconium-porphyrinic MOF hollow nanotubes were created using a solvothermal method. Subsequently, the SMAs were confined into zirconium-porphyrinic MOF hollow nanotubes using a facile solvothermal strategy. According to this strategy, the metal atoms can effectively hinder the agglomeration. As a result, the stabilized noble metal atoms were facilitated via bonding with four N atoms (Fig. 10(c)) The suitable selection of precursors is essential for designing SACs using a spatial confinement strategy, which could effectively stabilize SMA formation during the post-treatment process. Therefore, a rational design of the size, charge state of the mononuclear metal precursors, and suitable anchoring sites is crucial. 3.2.3 Defect or vacancy confinement strategy Defect or vacancy sites on the support surface could stabilize SMAs [67,155–158]. The defect or vacancy on the support surface could modify the neighboring electronic structure and coordination environment, thereby inducing an unsaturated coordination site and effectively preventing metal atom aggregation on the support surface. Because SMAs are usually immersed in the support, the possibility of SMAs being in direct contact with the reaction atmosphere is diminished. As a result, good stability for M-N-based SACs can be achieved [6,155,156,159]. For instance, Guo et al. [160] developed a method for constructing vacancy-based SACs within gCN (MSACs, M = noble metals). The metal atoms stabilized at the N vacancy sites. SMAs were coordinated with different amounts of N atoms with an M-N2/3 structure [160]. The existence of N vacancy could improve the N2 activation on the Pt single-atom site during the nitrogen reduction reaction. In addition, Guo et al. [161] also confined Pt atoms to the N vacancy sites in the gCN matrix. The N vacancy stabilized the Pt single-atom and two-coordinated C cites. Liu and his coworkers used electrostatic adsorption to confine Au single atoms on the gCN surface at the C vacancy sites. Before inserting the Au single atoms, the gCN was pretreated with alkali to increase the cationic properties of the gCN for more electropositivity, thereby favoring Au2+ adsorption onto the gCN surface. Through this pretreatment, the Au single atoms can be anchored via Au–N bonding at the C vacancy sites [162]. SMAs stabilized by the defect or vacancy sites are conveniently obtained, in which the metal atoms cannot be directly in contact with the reaction system. This type of SAC usually exhibits better stability than the SMAs stabilized on the support surface. As such, SMAs stabilized on the support surface outperformed SMAs stabilized by defects or vacancies. Meanwhile, the defect or vacancy on the support may cause an alteration in the electron distribution, which may affect catalytic performance. Thus, rationally designing a balanced ratio between defect or vacancy and support is essential for realizing M-N-based SACs with high catalytic activity. 4 Characterization techniques for determining geometric and electronic structures Having explored the synthesis methods of N-M SACs, confirming the electronic structure and coordinated structures of SACs is crucial to explicitly understand the interaction between SMAs and the support and development of highly efficient SACs [163]. Here, we focus on characterization techniques for examining the structural determination of SACs. Although transmission electron microscopy (TEM) can detect a catalyst's structure, the TEM resolution does not satisfy the nanoscale for revealing SMAs at the atomic level. The development of the aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field imaging scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) has successfully overcome TEM's deficiency. The HAADF-STEM resolution can reach 0.1 nm, resolving the atom structure at the atomic scale [72,143]. Usually, the location and spatial distribution of SMAs can be directly observed on the support surface using HAADF-STEM. For instance, atomically dispersed Pt atoms on the gCN surface could be directly observed using HAADFvSTEM (Fig. 11(a) ) [143]. However, although SMAs could be directly observed in the aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM, their observed specific element still requires identification. Therefore, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy and/or electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) synergized with STEM to confirm the observed SMA's specific element. Observably, Ni single atoms were atomically distributed on the WS2 surface (Fig. 11(b)). EELS exhibited atomically distributed Ni atoms without agglomeration, confirming the successful synthesis of C-based SACs [164]. HAADF-STEM combined with EELS provided a visual image of SMAs, which means that it can observe SMAs in a specific area, which induces misinterpretation of the observed results. Thus, synergizing HAADF-STEM with other characterization techniques is necessary. Based on the above demand, X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) based on synchrotron radiation has been widely employed to evaluate the interaction between SMAs and the support and coordination structures of SACs. XAS can be divided into X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), depending on the absorption energies. XANES represents the electronic structure and valence state of SACs, whereas the average bond length and coordination structure can be determined using EXAFS [165,166]. For instance, Xiong et al. [90] found that Co-SMAs incorporated on GO nanosheets were partially oxidized. The valance state of Co single atoms was between the standard Co foil and CoO. The EXAFS results indicated no Co-Co coordination in the Co-SACs. One O and three N atoms stabilized the Co atom by fitting the obtained EXAFS spectra. In particular, SACs should have a uniform local structure. Otherwise, the results obtained from XAS may contain some errors, which may impede the identification of the SAC fine structure (Figs. 12(a), (b) ) Scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) is another surface science technology for effectively observing SMAs at the atomic level. It can be used to observe both the electronic and geometric structures of M-N-based SACs [167]. For instance, STM can detect the coordinated structures of Fe atoms confined to graphene [167]. As presented in Figs. 12(c) and (d), the brightest plots in the matrix represent the single iron atoms. Furthermore, the simulated STM images of iron atoms confined in graphene demonstrate that the electronic structure of neighboring C and N atoms can be modified by the center iron single atom (Fig. 12(e)). Based on the above analysis, STEM combined with corresponding STM characterizations can effectively provide detailed structural information about SACs. However, the requirement of a uniformly flat support structure impedes the application of this method. 5 Application of M-N-based SACs 5.1 Photocatalytic applications 5.1.1 Photocatalytic water splitting Since Fujishima et al. [168] reported groundbreaking research on photocatalytic water splitting in 1972, current research on this topic has attracted great attention because solar energy can directly be converted into chemical energy via photocatalytic water splitting. Although various photocatalytic systems have been developed [169–181], the photocatalytic performance remains unsatisfactory [13,14]. Recently, numerous researchers have developed semiconductor-SAC photocatalysts with unique structures and electronic properties and that exhibit excellent photocatalytic performance compared with conventional semiconductor photocatalysts [46]. SACs have been successfully used in electrocatalysis. Electrochemical conversion methods, such as HER, ORR, and CO2 reduction, have attracted intensive research interests [182]. In previous research, the active catalytic sites mainly comprised NMB SMAs. Because of the high performance of SACs, the NMB content could be reduced to reach a lower cost. Non-NMB SACs also exhibited excellent catalytic activity and stability in electrochemistry systems. HER (the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism: H+ + e− → H*; H* + H+ + e− → H2 + * or the Volmer-Tafel mechanism H+ + e− → H*; 2H* → H2 + 2*) and OER (2H2O → 4e− + 4H+ + O2 at acidic conditions; 4OH− → 2O2 + 2H2O + 4e− at alkaline conditions) are fundamentally important for energy conversion. Oxidation and reduction reactions occur at the cathode and anode, respectively. Therefore, ultimately replacing or reducing the use of noble metal atoms is crucial. Noble metals, such as Pd, Pt, and Au, exhibit excellent performance in HER and OER [183]. Noble metal Pt as a cocatalyst has been widely used to improve photocatalytic performance, whereas traditional Pt nanoparticle cocatalysts have been partially used, thereby increasing the cost of catalytic systems. As SMAs are individually dispersed on the semiconductor's surface, every SMA can serve as an active site. Cao et al. [144] constructed Pt single atoms serving as hydrogen-evolution sites on the gCN surface by forming “Pt-N4” moiety (Fig. 13(a) ), which could accelerate the photogenerated electrons and optimize the water reduction kinetics. DFT calculations indicated that the Pt 5d orbital strongly hybridized with the N 2p orbital effectively shifts the d-band center to the Fermi energy, thereby significantly decreasing the H absorption free energy (Fig. 13(b)). Thus, the average lifetimes of pure gCN and Pt-NP-gCN exceeded that of Pt-SA-gCN; the Pt-SA-gCN showed a TOF of 250 h−1, which was 13 times the Pt-NP-gCN's TOF [144] (Figs. 13(c), (d)). Besides serving as a cocatalyst, a single metal also influences the light absorption of semiconductors. Xiong et al. [184] created a metal-to-ligand charge-transfer concept between a single Pt and gCN. Pt2+ cations were coordinated with the sp 2-bonded N atoms (Fig. 14(a) ). As the Pt2+ concentration increased, the light absorption of gCN-Pt2+ was gradually improved (from 460 to 800 nm) (Fig. 14(b)). Notably, the gCN with different amounts of Pt2+ exhibited a similar photocatalytic performance at the 420-nm monochromatic light. This means that hydrogen generation occurred at the site on gCN; therefore, the introduction of Pt2+ into gCN does not contribute to the active site (Fig. 14(c)). The density of state (DOS) results indicated that a new state emerged at 1.2 eV, which was more positive than the original HOMO state of gCN, which was attributed to the hybridization of Pt2+ with the HOMO of C3N4 aromatic rings (Fig. 14(d)). Here, we mentioned that the energy gap of the metal-to-ligand process was 1.8 eV, corresponding to light absorption enhancement (Fig. 14(e)). Based on this consideration, gCN-Pt2+ exhibited a hydrogen generation rate of 605 μmol g−1 h−1. However, the photocatalytic activity did not significantly change as the Pt content increased, suggesting that Pt was not anchored at the active sites. Therefore, coordinating SMAs precisely at the active site is critical. Apart from considering the coordination bond and valence state of M-N-based SACs, the dynamic evolution is also helpful in understanding the underlying mechanisms for photocatalytic water splitting. Bi et al. [6] found that the cleavage of the Pt–N bond could reduce its oxidation state to Pt0 species, which was accompanied by the conversion from the C–N to C = N bond during the photocatalytic HER measured using synchronous illumination XPS. Compared with the ground state, the deconvoluted peaks of −N−C = N component (in the core level of C 1s and N 1s) and metallic Pt in the Pt 4f signal were significantly enhanced. However, the peaks of Pt–N bonding at the core level of Pt 4f and C-N at the core level of C 1s abruptly decreased, indicating that the Pt–N bonds were broken and substantial intensity of Pt and C = signals were generated (Figs. 15(a)–(c) ). Meanwhile, the Pt-N-coordinated bond breaking and the reduction from Pt0 species could reduce electron density at low binding energies and strengthen the reduction ability (Figs. 15(d) and (e)). Therefore, the Pt2+ atoms could drastically attract electrons from the gCN planar layer under light irradiation and be converted into Pt0 atoms. The single Pt0 with abundant electrons reacted with water to generate hydrogen (Figs. 15(f)) [6]. Although noble metal single-atom cocatalysts have exhibited their excellent performance in photocatalytic HER, the lack of development in this field is caused by the high price and limited number of rare-earth constituents. Therefore, finding effective alternatives to noble metal SACs is highly desirable. For example, Cao et al. [185] found that the Co1-N4 structure enhanced electron density and lowered H-H coupling (Fig. 16(a) ). Here, the Co center sites could significantly enhance the electron density near the N atoms. Thus, the electrons easily transferred from the N site to Co atoms via the Co–N bond and reduced the CoII to CoI. Compared with the other N and C atoms, the H atoms were preferably adsorbed by the N atoms located directly near the Co atoms. As a result, the Co sites adsorbed H* and protonated by forming CoIII-H hydride complexes. These intermediates play a crucial role in accelerating photocatalytic HER. Then, the H* on the Co and N sites synergize to form H2 (Fig. 16(b)). Thus, the introduction of Co1-N4 reduced the average exciton lifetime from 5.98 ns for pure gCN to 0.72 ns for Co-PCN (Fig. 16(c)). As a result, the obtained Co-PCN photocatalysts exhibit a robust hydrogen-evolution rate of 10.8 μmol h−1 with an AQE of 3.02% at 450 nm [185]. The above reports explored only the single metals coordinated with the N atoms. Coordination with heteroatoms and N atoms can alter the electronic structure around SMAs. The valence state of the SMA center plays a significant role in photocatalytic HER. Jin et al. [186] designed Ni single atoms coordinated by one C atom and four N atoms (Fig. 17(a) ). They controlled the chemical valence of the Ni single-atom site by partially oxidizing Ni single atoms, reaching electron configuration modulation (Fig. 17(b)). The coordination number and unpaired electrons decreased (Figs. 17(c)–(f)). The VB comprised unpaired Ni 3d electrons and accelerated the CB crossing the Fermi level, thereby reducing the gCN bandgap. Accordingly, the Ni single atoms could improve the visible-light response (Figs. 17(h) and (i)) [187–189]. Thus, the photocatalytic performance of the partially oxidized Ni-gCN (CN-0.2Ni-OH) outperformed those of oxidized Ni-gCN (CN-0.2Ni-O) and non-oxidized Ni-gCN(CN-0.2Ni-H) (Fig. 17(j)) [186]. By summarizing the above overview, we proposed that M-N-based SACs could efficiently enhance photocatalytic HER performance over semiconductor photocatalysts. However, the accompanying oxygen evolution half-reaction has been ignored. In addition, sacrificial agents, such as TEOA and lactic acid, are indispensable in this M-N-based SAC photocatalytic system and are unfavorable for the development of efficient and low-cost photocatalytic systems. Therefore, subsequent work should explore the development of overall water-splitting M-N-C-based SAC photocatalytic systems. 5.1.2 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction In recent years, global warming triggered by the greenhouse effect has become an imminent threat. This problem, mainly related to carbon dioxide exposure in the atmosphere, has received considerable attention [190]. Converting CO2 into high-value chemical fuels has been an effective method for tackling greenhouse gas effects. Therefore, the photocatalytic method is a convenient method for realizing CO2 reduction [191–198]. Among the previous research on the photocatalytic system for CO2 reduction, M-N-based SACs were considered as the candidate materials for photocatalytic CO2 reduction [7]. Usually, single semiconductor photocatalysts cannot directly break the C=O bond in the aldehyde group due to the low electron cloud density on the semiconductor's surface. In contrast, the SMA sites on the semiconductors’ surfaces could act as active sites, which results in a high electron cloud density around the metal site and in the breaking of the C=O bond. Yang et al. [199] constructed an Au single-atom-modified amino-group-enriched gCN. The Au single atoms with a valence state of +1 were anchored by the Au-N3 structure (Fig. 18(a) ). The presence of another intermediate reaction allows for the expected process upon anchoring on Au atoms. To facilitate the desired target, the existence of Au-N3 structure reduces the energy activation barrier of the subsequent chemical reaction; thus, the CO2 adsorption using Au-gCN is more promising than pure gCN. Furthermore, the bonding between positively charged Au+ with N could result in high electron cloud density, enhancing the photogenerated electron transfer to Au+, thus improving the separation rate of carriers (Figs. 18(b), (c)). The CH4 production rate was about 4.15 times that of pure gCN (Fig. 18(d)) [199]. The change in the electronic structure of the metal sites during CO2 reduction is critical. Ji and his coworkers [159] designed Er-modified gCN nanotube SACs for photocatalytic CO2 reduction in a pure water system. Six Er-N coordination bonds stabilized the Er single atom (Fig. 19(a) ). The loading content of the Er atoms reached 2.5 wt% (LD-Er1-CN-NT) to 20.1 wt% (HD-Er1-CN-NT). The valence state of Er in the SACs was determined in the range of 0–3+. In addition, the oxidation state of the Er species in LD-Er1-CN-NT exceeded that in HD-Er1-CN-NT (Fig. 19(b)). During the photocatalytic reaction, the valence state of Er gradually decreased due to the electronic transfer from the active Er center to the C 2p orbital in CO2 to generate a CO2 δ− species, suggesting that the Er center was the active site (Fig. 19(c)). As a result, the CH4 and CO evolution rates of LD-Er1-CN-NT were 0.45 and 12.75 µmol g−1 h−1, respectively. The CH4 and CO evolution rates of HD-Er1-CN-NT were 2.5 and 47.1 µmol g−1 h−1 (Fig. 19(d)), significantly exceeding those of pure gCN [159]. Cao et al. [200] Cu atoms on the gCN by supramolecular preorganization with subsequent condensation method provides effective charge-transfer pathways by an “infused” delocalized state with variable-valence catalysis. Two N atoms and one C atom stabilized the Cu single atoms. CO2 molecules could be activated at the SMA sites in photocatalytic CRR [200]. Although M-N based SACs have demonstrated excellent photocatalytic performance in photocatalytic COR, their reaction pathways remain unclear. Wang et al. [201] constructed iron SACs for photocatalytic CO2 reduction using an electrofiltration method. The SMAs were anchored onto the as-prepared nitrogen-doped carbon using the Fe-N4 structure. Thus, the formation of the Fe–N–C bond could effectively transfer electrons from photosensitizers to atomically dispersed iron atoms with a valence state between 0 and +2 (Figs. 20(a) and (b) ). As a result, the average generation rates of CO and H2 with a tunable CO/H2 ratio ranging from 0.3 to 8.8 could reach 4500 and 4950 μmol g−1 h−1, respectively (Fig. 20(c)). Contrarily, Fe2++ N/C, N/C, and Fe2+ exhibited negligible photocatalytic performance under the same condition. Consequently, the single iron atoms are determined as active sites in SACs. The underlying reason for the effective photocatalytic performance of Fe SAC existing in the Fe-N4-C structure is the significant reduction in the free energies to form the intermediates of COOH* and H* compared with the N4-C structure (Fig. 20(d)). In addition, the free energies of adsorbed CO decrease from + 0.61e to −0.27e after anchoring iron single atoms (Figs. 20(e) and (f)). Thus, the electron may transfer from the Fe 3d orbital to the CO orbital [201]. Recently, Xiang et al. [202] found that a dual-SMA active site could synergistically regulate cooperative photocatalysis. Co and Ru single atoms were coordinated on the gCN surface. Co-active sites could accelerate charge transfer. Meanwhile, the Ru active sites could enhance selective CO2 surface-bound interaction during the CO2 photoreduction [202]. Furthermore, M-N single-metal sites could serve as CO2 adsorption sites. Bao et al. [30] demonstrated that Cu single atoms on the gCN surface could increase adsorption capacity and reduce entropy decrease for CO2 to CO. Thus, the gCN/Cu displayed nearly 100% selective CO2 to CO conversion [30]. The coordinated electronic structure also plays a significant role in CO2 reduction. Zang et al. [203] replaced N with O in Ni-N4 SACs. The electron transfer and adsorption of the reaction radicals of *COOH could be enhanced by introducing O into the phthalocyanine-based Ni-N4 framework [203]. Although a great amount of effort has been devoted to improving photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance, unknown underlying mechanisms still require further study. A fundamental understanding of the difference in the catalytic mechanisms between semiconductor catalysts and M-N-based SACs, which were derived from pyrolysis, is imperative. In summary, single-metal sites serve as the activity sites that facilitate the adsorption of *CO/*COOH intermediates. However, how neighboring N and C atoms influence the catalytic process remains unexplored. Several plausible relationships between the SMA site and the coordinating atoms remain the ongoing challenges to resolving the CO2 reduction mechanism on the M-N-C-based SACs. 5.1.3 Other photocatalytic applications Xie et al. [204] constructed Cu single-atom-modified gCN for photocatalytic ammonia synthesis (Fig. 21(a) ). The single-formed Cu–N bond could activate the conjugated π-electron cloud of gCN. Then, the strong triple bonds between two nitrogen atoms could be cracked by the photoexcited electrons transferred from the CB of the gCN ion to the Cu2+. The in situ FTIR results found the new formation of the σ(N–H) bending mode during light irradiation (1553 cm−1), indicating that water was adsorbed on the N atoms and thereby mediated the protons to combine with the dinitrogen molecule generating NH3 (Fig. 21(b)). The SMAs were stabilized in the defect of gCN with threefold coordination N atoms from the π conjugated electron cloud. The electrons in the VB could be quickly excited under light irradiation (Figs. 21(c)–(f)). Thus, the Cu-CN could reach an ammonia-evolution rate of 186 μmol g−1 h−1 [204]. Li et al. [205] demonstrated that SMA Pt could effectively enhance the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes. The Pt single atoms could narrow the bandgap by increasing the CB level of the CTF-PDDA-TPDH, which enhanced the reducibility of the photogenerated electrons (Figs. 22(a), (b) ). More importantly, the formation of the Pt-N3 site as the active center could alter the mechanism of nitrogen fixation to ammonia. The adsorption energy of N2 molecule adsorbed at the SAMs was −0.97 eV. In addition, to deeply understand the mechanism, the first step, hydrogen evolution of adsorbed N2, and the second step, the release of NH3, are endergonic. The onset potential of the generation of the first NH3 was 1.43 eV. However, in the traditional reaction process, the onset potential of NH3 generation was 1.26 eV (Figs. 22(c), (d)). Thus, the altering mechanism, onset potential, favors the N2 fixation with an ammonia-evolution rate of 171.40 μmol g−1 h−1 without any sacrificial agent. Guo and his coworkers [206] demonstrated that Mo single atoms could also be the main active sites for photocatalytic ambient nitrogen fixation in pure water. Compared with pure gCN, the Mo-N2 active center could easily adsorb N2 molecules (Figs. 23(a), (b) ). Here, we demonstrate the distance of two N atoms in the N2 molecule that was extended from 1.11 to 1.15 Å (Fig. 23(d)). The weakened N≡N bond decreased the electron-transfer energy barrier from the Mo center cites to the N2 molecule. The photocatalytic performance indicated that the gCN with different amounts of Mo single atoms exhibited a comparable photocatalytic NH3 generated rate of 14.7 mmol gMo −1 h−1 in pure water (Fig. 23(d)). The stabilized Mo atoms could effectively promote electron transfer from the CB of the gCN to the Mo center by time-resolved fluorescence kinetics (Fig. 23(e)) [206]. 5.2 Electrocatalytic application 5.2.1 Electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution (HER) The NMB electrocatalysts showed excellent performance in electrocatalytic HER due to their small Tafel slope and high exchange current density. However, high costs significantly limit their wide applications. Therefore, many non-NMB electrocatalysts, such as Ni, Co, Mo, Fe, and their derivatives, have been developed [207–211]. Notably, the electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalysts relies on the active metal center, which can be regulated by decreasing the size of the active center to expose more surface area and by modulating the electronic structure to adjust the adsorption properties, respectively. Thus, M-N-based SACs provide a new pathway for electrocatalytic HER. For example, Fei et al. [212] constructed Co single atoms on N-doped graphene for electrocatalytic HER (Fig. 24(a) ). The overpotential and Tafel slope of Co-NG SACs reached 30 and 82 mV dec−1, respectively. Meanwhile, the Co-NG maintained stability in acid and alkaline atmospheres (Figs. 24(b)–(d)). The HER performance hardly changed as the Co content increased. The exclusive Co content forms cobalt oxide. The N doping could create active sites in the Co-NG SACs. The doping temperature is necessary for Co-N coordination bond formation. Therefore, Co-NG shows an excellent HER performance compared with Co-G [212]. Although SMAs stabilized by four N atoms (M-N4 structure) exhibit excellent electrocatalytic HER performance, the strong electronegativity of the coordination N atoms near the central metal atoms directly induces a large reaction Gibbs free energy for intermediate adsorption on the surface of the active metal site, which reduces the kinetic process rate of catalytic reactions [213]. Considering the disadvantage of the M-N4 structure, Wan and his coworkers [214] replaced the N atoms (Co-SA-without P) with relatively weak electronegativity P atoms to form the Co-P1N3 structure (Fig. 25(a) ). The atom distances between Co-P and Co-N were 2.18 and 1.95 Å, respectively (Fig. 25(b)). The valence state of Co was gradually oxidized under working conditions from −60 mV (1.53) to −120 mV (1.78), suggesting that Co single atoms served as the active site during the HER (Fig. 25(c)). Both Co–N and Co–P bonds extended during the catalytic process, suggesting that the extended high valence bond under working conditions could be responsible for the high HER performance (Fig. 25(d)). The adsorption energy of the H atom decreased from 0.306 to 0.022 eV after replacing N with P (Fig. 25(e)). Thus, hydrogen was easily adsorbed on the Co-P1N3 site during the HER (Fig. 25(f)). The introduction of relatively weak electronegativity P atoms could optimize the Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption. As a result, the overpotential and TOF of Co-SA/P in situ were 98 and 47 mV dec−1, respectively (Figs. 25(g)–(i)), which outperformed those of Co-SA-without P (148 and 61 mV dec−1) [214]. Harzandi et al. [215] demonstrated that the photocatalytic performances of SACs do not always outperform those of NPs and miscible bimetal alloys. Therefore, Cu/Ru bimetal single atoms for electrocatalytic HER are proposed. This material improves the HER performance and enhances the durability of HER. DFT calculations suggested that N atoms and bridge coordinated the Cu single atom to the Ru-NP surface by a CuN3-Ru structure (Cu/Ru@GN) (Fig. 26(a) ). The introduction of Cu atoms created new active sites and induced long-term stability for Ru NPs@GN. An obvious Cu-N peak was observed in the EXAFS of the Cu-foil. Another prominent peak at about 2.44 Å was attributed to the Cu–Ru bond (Fig. 26(b)). Meanwhile, no Ru–O bond was observed in EXAFS at the O2 atmosphere after introducing Cu single atoms. Concurrently, pure Ru NPs exhibited an obvious Ru-O peak at 1.68 Å in the EXAFS, suggesting that the introduction of Cu single atoms has a slight effect in protecting Ru NPs from oxidation (Figs. 26(d), (e)). Thus, the obtained Cu/Ru@GN maintained long-term stability of more than 500 h in acidic media. The DFT results indicated that high positive Bader charges of Ru single atoms and surface Ru NPs in Cu/Ru@GN were 0.31 and 0.20, respectively, suggesting that these positively charged Ru could maintain stability during the HER process. Cu single atoms coordinated with N atoms on the Ru-NP surface could decrease ΔG H* on the Ru fcc-sites near the Cu-SAs of Cu-N3Ru (NP); thus, the Ru fcc sites are extra-active sites (Fig. 26(f)). As a result, the Cu/Ru@GN exhibits excellent HER performance with a low overpotential of 10 mV at a current density of 10 mA·cm−2 (Fig. 26(c)) [215]. Yu and his coworkers [216] used the electronic metal-support interaction method to co-sponsored mesoporous hollow carbon spheres (NMHCS) to confine Pt single atoms. The Pt single atoms/NMHCS exhibited much better performance and stability than the Pt nanoparticles. The Pt atoms were coordinated by one N atom and two C atoms. This coordination structure favored the reduction of the adsorbed proton and facilitated H−H coupling. 5.2.2 Electrocatalytic oxygen evolution (OER) Although NMB electrocatalysts have demonstrated excellent performance, the rare abundance of noble metals restricts their further applications. For example, these materials cannot show excellent simultaneous performance in acidic and alkaline media [96]. Recently, M-N-C SACs have been considered candidates for electrocatalytic OER owing to their high catalytic performance and uniform-structural active sites. Zheng et al. [95] constructed Co-gCN SACs via a molecular configuration, in which two adjacent pyridinic-N atoms stabilized the Co single atoms by a Co-N2 matrix. Under an overpotential of 0.35 eV for OER, the OOH* formation step was uphill (Fig. 27(a) ). The DFT calculation demonstrated that the coordinated Co species exhibited higher activity than the uncoordinated cobalt oxide. In addition, additional electron distribution around the Co-N2 matrix enhanced the OH* adsorption (Figs. 27(c)–(e)) so that the Co-N2 matrix could adsorb intermediates and accelerate carrier transfer during the OER. As a result, the obtained Co-gCN/CNT delivered an overpotential of 1.61 V at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH solution (Fig. 27(b)) [95]. Recently, researchers have reported graphene-based M-N-C SACs in electrocatalytic OER. Graphene-supported single-atom Co and Fe were prepared using the in situ electrochemical method, resulting in an overpotential of 309 mV at 10 mA/cm2 and a Tafel slope of 37 mV/dec (Figs. 28(a) and (b) ) [120]. Moreover, the ECSA increased about three times after incorporating single iron atoms. The incorporation of Fe significantly decreased the overpotential of Co-N-C. Co-Fe-N-C exhibited excellent OER performance compared with iron incorporated in CoNPs-N-C (Fig. 28(c)). In Co-N-C, the Co atoms were five coordinated with the surrounding one O, one C, and three N atoms. After incorporating the Fe single atom, a new scattering path (Co-Fe) was formed, and the Co was coordinated with 1 N, 1 C, and Fe. Then, 4 OH−/OH2 groups originated from the electrolyte (Fig. 28(d)). The Co-Fe dimeric unit acted as the active site during the ORR reaction [120]. The electronic structure of the SMA center could be modified by introducing different coordinated atomistic structures. For example, Zhang et al. designed various M-N coordination bonds with S-doped SACs owing to the different affinities of Fe and Co/Ni ions toward the S-containing ligands [217]. In the Fe-SACs, the Fe single atom was stabilized by four N and two S atoms from the FeN4S2 center sites, whereas the Co and Ni atoms were bonded with three N and one S atoms from the NiN4S1 and CoN4S1 center sites (Fig. 29(a) ). In addition, the FeN4S2 center site of the SACs exhibited better ORR performance than the NiN4S1 and CoN4S1 center sites of the SACs due to the M-S coordinated bond. As the electronegativity of N exceeded that of S, the electrons were transferred from S to N. The calculated charge density of Fe in FeN4S2 also exceeded that of Ni and Co in NiN4S1 and CoN4S1 (Fig. 29(B)), which could enhance the electron density near the Fe center, resulting in enhanced ORR performance (Fig. 29(c)) [217]. The above works demonstrate that the M-N-based SACs show excellent performance. However, how does the electronic structure change when replacing N atoms with other atoms? Song et al. [218] differentiated between N-Co-N and O-Co-N active centers. The N-Co-N active center was constructed by Co stabilization with two neighboring pyridinic-N atoms. The O-Co-N center was created by Co coordinating with O atoms and being introduced in the cages of gCN (Fig. 30(a) ). The M–N bonds could effectively accelerate the migration of electrons owing to the high affinity of nitrogen for metal ions. Concurrently, electrons could migrate from the metal cation to oxygen adsorbates by the M–O bond. Thus, Co atoms anchored on ultrathin gCN@carbon spheres exhibited excellent OER performance. At a low overpotential, the OER performance of O-Co-N exceeded that of N-Co-N, but at a high overpotential, the OER performance of N-Co-N surpassed that of O-Co-N (Fig. 30(b)). At a low overpotential, the higher electronegativity of O atoms could promote the adsorption of oxygen species, inducing better OER performance. In contrast, at a high overpotential, excessively adsorbing oxygen species affects the subsequent desorption process, which induces poor OER performance. Meanwhile, at a high overpotential, every step of N-Co-N goes downhill. However, O-Co-N exhibits a high potential barrier at Step IV, suggesting that the N−Co−N bond has better electron-transfer ability than the O−Co−N bond at a high potential (Figs. 30(c), (d)) [218]. The content of SMAs usually affects the catalytic performance of M-N-based SACs. Yu et al. [219] constructed high-loading Fe-N4 SACs based on o-phenylenediamine support. The catalytic activity of Fe-N4 SACs in the OER was improved by increasing SMA loading. The best Fe-N4 SACs displayed an onset potential of 0.97 V and a half-wave potential of 0.85 V [219]. We discussed two main factors affecting the OER performance from the aforementioned description: geometry and electronic effects. Several strategies, such as alloying the isolated active metal with SAMs, have been designed to realize this modulation [220]. However, these strategies can decrease the accessible active metal ensembles in space and adjust the electronic structure. 5.2.3 Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction Over the past year, many electrocatalysts have been designed for CO2 reduction [221–224]. For example, Ag and Au are widely used for the selective reduction of CO2 to CO [225–227]. Notably, Cu as the CRR catalyst could induce the formation of (oxygenated) hydrocarbon end products, such as ethanol [228], ethylene [229,230], or methane [231], during the CRR. Compared with metallic electrodes or electrocatalysts, the M-N-based SACs exhibited better performance for CRR. The M-N-based SACs could leverage the metal site and adsorb the active carbonaceous reaction intermediates and exhibit high catalytic performance and selectivity [47,232]. Gong and his coworkers [233] used Mg2+ to disperse the adjacent Ni atoms and stabilize the Ni atoms by the N source in the polypyrrole guest during pyrolysis (Fig. 31(a) ). The Ni single atoms with different N coordination numbers were successfully constructed via different pyrolysis temperatures. The charge-transfer resistance of NiSA-N2-C surpassed those of NiSA-N3-C and NiSA-N4-C. Thus, the Ni atoms with two N coordination catalysts demonstrated a Faradaic efficiency of 98% and a turnover frequency of 1622 h−1 (Figs. 31(b), (c)). The DFT results indicated that the desorption energies of NiSA-N3-C and NiSA-N4-C significantly exceeded that of NiSA-N2-C (0.47 eV) (Fig. 31(d)) [233]. Fe single atoms also acted as an effective active center for electron CRR. Zhang et al. [234] designed Fe single atoms atomically dispersed on nitrogen-doped graphene, showing low overpotential reduction with a high Faradic efficiency of 80% (Figs. 32(a), (b) ). The Fe atoms were coordinated with four N atoms embedded in NG. The two graphitic N-modified Fe-N4 moieties could decrease the formation of an energy barrier of COOH* from 0.63 to 0.29 eV and CO adsorption energy from 0.5 to 0.3 eV (Figs. 33(c), (d) ). Thus, Fe-NG exhibited excellent electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance [42]. Although SACs exhibit excellent performance in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, the CO2 reduction mechanism is still insufficient due to the limited model system. Liu et al. [234] constructed Ni SACs with a well-defined Ni-N4 moiety to explore the CO2 reduction mechanism. They approximately found that a lower energy of 0.3 eV in the rising edge was observed under cathodic bias via Operando XAS in Ar-saturated KHCO3 solution, indicating that the Ni atoms were reduced from Ni2+ to Ni+. After adding CO2 to saturation, the Ni atoms were oxidized from Ni+ to Ni2+ (Figs. 32(a), (b)). The same phenomenon occurred in the operand Raman spectra. By increasing the applied cathodic potential in the Ar atmosphere, the Ni-N vibration peaks shifted to lower wavenumbers. In the CO2 atmosphere, the Ni-N vibration peak maintained the initial wavenumbers (Figs. 32(c), (d)). Therefore, they demonstrated that the Ni+ atoms in the prepared SACs served as authentic catalytically active sites for CO2 reduction. During the CO2 reduction, Ni2+ sites in Ni SACs were first reduced to Ni+. Then, the addition of CO2 combined with Ni+ sites by the Ni–C bond and oxidized the Ni+ to Ni2+. Subsequently, the hydrogenation step *CO2− + H+ → *COOH occurred. Finally, the desorption of CO from the active site was achieved (Fig. 32(e)) [234]. Considering the previous review, M-N-based SACs exhibited excellent catalytic activity at electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Coordinated structures also play a significant role in M-N-based SACs. Lin et al. [29] found that coordinated structures affect the binding strength and adsorption capacity of CO2, and Co atoms coordinated with 4 N atoms exhibited high desorption temperature than that of Co atoms coordinated with N4–X CX atoms, indicating stronger binding strength between the catalyst and adsorbate. Jiang et al. [235] found that the Ni coordination number in Ni-N-C affected the reaction process. The formation of the Ni-N3-C active center could obviously enhance COOH* formation, accelerating CO2 reduction [235]. 6 Computational tools The DFT theory is widely used to study the atomic-scale properties of SACs and their function in the adsorption and reaction processes. Here, we summarize the theoretical approaches widely used in SACs. With the combination of DFT calculations and advanced characterization techniques, we deeply summarize our understanding of the fundamental properties, such as stability, electronic features, and reaction mechanisms of SACs. 6.1 Models The plane wave approach and generalized gradient approximation are usually used to optimize the structure of the spin-polarized periodic DFT to determine the exchange-correlation functional in the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation implemented in solid-state programs. The electronic wave functions and core electron basis with sufficient kinetic cutoff energy were conducted using a frozen-core all-electron projector-augmented wave [236]. Monkhorst conducted the numerical integrations in the reciprocal space and ground-state atomic geometries—the pack scheme of k-points mesh and the minimization of the Hellmann-Feynman forces, respectively. 6.2 Methods The binding and cohesive energies of SMAs to the support for SACs represent the binding strength between metal atoms and support. The electronic structure of the SACs could be measured using the DOSs and Bader charge calculations. These calculations provide insights into the formation of the new chemical bonding between the SMAs and support, indicating a hint about carrier migration by understanding the atoms contained in this reaction and the amount of migration charges. These calculation methods explain the orbital's nature in the chemical bond between SMAs and support by identifying the amount of transferred charge, which provides possible evidence for charge transfers. The climbing-image nudged elastic band method usually analyzes the transition states along progress pathways [139]. The start and final states of all models are measured, and the final reactants and products are the lowest energies in the minimum energy path. All calculations are usually performed at the generalized gradient approximation level of the DFT, including dispersion correction terms. 7 Conclusions and future prospects To evaluate, formulate, and maximize the strengths of M-N-based SACs, we outlined several factors influencing the utilization of active sites. According to comprehensive insights, it is important to unravel the role of intrinsic activity in SACs to develop catalytic activity and extend their practical applications. Here, we summarize the synthesis method of M-N-based SACs and their in the photocatalytic and electrocatalytic areas. We then systematically discuss the relationship between the electronic structure, catalytic activity, and underlying catalytic mechanism for each application. Although M-N-based SACs have demonstrated excellent catalytic performance, exploration of the potential of other synthesis methods for central and coordination atoms to boost catalytic performance in photocatalytic and electronic applications is imperative. Here, some perspectives and challenges are proposed (Fig. 33). (1) Optimizing synthesis method and developing non-NMB M-N-based SACs with stable coordination structure and high catalytic performance. In the HTP discussion, we provided three categories covering HTP MOF-based precursors, N-containing irregular complexes, or polymer-based precursors. In addition, we summarized three categories related to the coordination design, spatial confinement, and defect or vacancy confinement strategies interacting with the surface anchoring sites. Although progress in this field has expanded, an obstacle exists in translating the usage of M-N-based SACs for upscaling to mass production. The biggest limitation is the low content of the loading SMA site, which significantly inhibits the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Therefore, it is highly desirable to design efficient synthetic methods for constructing a high-loading content of single-metal active sites. Single-metal catalysts synthesized by a coordination design strategy are usually directly in contact with the reaction system. Although this approach exhibits a higher loading content of single active sites than the conventional pathway, the stability of SACs is poor. In addition, the structural stability of SACs is an important indicator of efficient catalytic performance. For M-N-based SACs, the carbon support is susceptible to high electron potential. Consequently, the active sites of single-metal sites could also be disrupted during the electrooxidation reaction. Thus, an effort to improve the graphitization degree of the carbon support is underway toward structural stability during the electrooxidized reaction. Therefore, a strategy for preserving SACs using a coordination design strategy still faces a significant challenge. We systematically discuss the relationship between electronic structure and catalytic activity and the underlying catalytic mechanism for each application. In addition, most NMB M-N-based SACs demonstrate better catalytic performance and stability than the NMB M-N-based SACs. However, the former has a drawback due to the high cost of the catalysts. Therefore, formulating alternative-NMB M-N-based SACs is important for reducing the cost of the catalysts. (2) Understanding the synthesized mechanism and constructing regulated structures and active sites. Furthermore, although M-N-based SACs could be easily obtained using the HTP method, the structure of SACs cannot be precisely controlled after HTP, thereby inducing an unclear structure and active sites. Therefore, a non-HTP method for constructing M-N-based SACs is required to effectively determine the precise structure and understand the well-defined active sites. Recently, conjugated polymers, such as COFs, MOFs, conjugated porous polymers, and covalent triazine frameworks, have been widely used in the photocatalytic area. In particular, donor-acceptor-type conjugated polymers exhibit excellent photocatalytic performance due to the pull-push effects. Photogenerated electrons are commonly dispersed in the acceptor. Bipyridine and 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole with an N site usually serve as acceptors. Meanwhile, the N in the acceptor usually acts as an active site. Bonding the SMAs with the N site could effectively transfer the photogenerated electrons to the single-metal site. It is better to understand the photocatalytic process during photocatalytic reactions. (3) Resolving the influence of electronic structure and geometric structure on catalytic performance. The coordination number also plays a significant role in the catalytic performance of M-N-based SACs. For instance, a different electronic structure influences the reaction step and alters the reaction mechanism. This reduces the activation energy, providing a vast opportunity for investigating the electrochemical process and mechanism at the atomic scale by synergizing experiments and theory. The extensive computation details on the reaction mechanism will significantly facilitate the designing efficiency of M-N-based SACs. In addition, several studies have demonstrated that M-N-based SACs are successfully anchored on various structure supports. Concurrently, the influences of structural support on the catalytic performance of M-N-based SACs remain conflicting. To develop efficient M-N-based SAC frameworks for catalytic applications, several key ingredients should be addressed, including the metal loading content enhancement of SACs, structural stability, and catalytic performance. Resolving the influence of electronic and geometric structures on catalytic performance remains an open challenge for SAC development. (4) More advanced characterization techniques should be used to deeply understand the dynamical evolution and regeneration of M-N-based SACs. How M-N-based SACs work under a real reaction atmosphere still lacks detailed mechanisms. Therefore, various in situ techniques, such as IR spectra, STEM, and XAFS, have been used to determine the structures of N-M-based SACs. Meanwhile, some state-of-the-art characterization techniques could be used to determine M-N-based SACs. For example, cryogenic TEM has been widely used in structural biology and lithium-metal batteries. Owing to high-energy electron irradiation, supports, such as carbon materials and MOFs, may collapse during TEM characterizations and aggregate with SMAs. Therefore, cryogenic TEM and other advanced characterization techniques are important for future advances in M-N-based SACs. Nowadays, SACs have exhibited excellent catalytic activities on a laboratory scale. Shortly, we portray that this intriguing frame holds great value for large-scale industrialization. Hence, to successfully integrate M-N-based SACs toward promising renewable and cost-effective energy systems, further studies are encouraged to develop a well-defined fundamental background from a material engineering perspective. This will ultimately trigger an extensive manufacturing layout and techno-economic analysis. Acknowledgments X. Xin Li received his B.S. and PhD degrees in Chemical Engineering from Zhengzhou University in 2002 and South China University of Technology in 2007, respectively. Then, he joined South China Agricultural University as a faculty staff member, and became a professor in 2017. During 2012 and 2019, he worked as a visiting scholar at the Electrochemistry Center, the University of Texas at Austin, and Department of Chemistry, the University of Utah, respectively. His research interests include photocatalysis, photoelectrochemistry, adsorption, biomass engineering and the related materials and devices development (see http://www.researcherid.com/ rid/A-2698-2011). Yun Hau Ng is an associate professor in the School of Energy and Environment, City University of Hong Kong. He received his PhD from Osaka University in 2009. Before joining City University of Hong Kong, he was a lecturer (2014) and senior lecturer (2016) in the School of Chemical Engineering, University of New South Wales. His research is focused on the development of novel photoactive semiconductors for sunlight energy conversion. He received the 2021 Kataoka Lectureship Award for Asian and Oceanian Photochemist, the APEC ASPIRE Prize in 2019, Distinguished Lectureship Award from the Chemical Society of Japan in 2018, and Honda-Fujishima Prize by the Electrochemical Society of Japan in 2013.

coredata.dc:description: Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have been widely used in heterogeneous catalysis owing to the maximum utilization of metal-active sites with controlled structures and well-defined locations. Upon tailored coordination with nitrogen atom, the metal-nitrogen (M-N)-based SACs have demonstrated interesting physical, optical and electronic properties and have become intense in photocatalysis and electrocatalysis in the past decade. Despite substantial efforts in constructing various M–N-based SACs, the principles for modulating the intrinsic photocatalytic and electrocatalytic performance of their active sites and catalytic mechanism have not been sufficiently studied. Herein, the present review intends to shed some light on recent research made in studying the correlation between intrinsic electronic structure, catalytic mechanism, single-metal atom (SMA) confinement and their photocatalytic and electrocatalytic activities (conversion, selectivity, stability and etc). Based on the analysis of fundamentals of M–N-based SACs, theoretical calculations and experimental investigations, including synthetic methods and characterization techniques, are both included to provide an integral understanding of the underlying mechanisms behind improved coordination structure and observed activity. Finally, the challenges and perspectives for constructing highly active M–N based photocatalysis and electrocatalysis SACs are provided. In particular, extensive technical and mechanism aspects are thoroughly discussed, summarized and analyzed for promoting further advancement of M-N-based SACs in photocatalysis and electrocatalysis.
